Name: Alexanders (Maceron)
Notes: Alexanders is a biennial herbaceous plant with a thick elongated root. The stems grow up to 150 cm and hollow on fruiting. It has large, pinnatisect, basal leaves, with ovate to subrhombic terminal segments; the caulinar leaves are pinnatisect. The umbels have seven to 22 rays, with black. didymous fruit measuring 5.5 to 7.5 x 4 to 7.5 mm. Alexanders flowers from April to June and propagates well from seed. Succeeds in most soils but prefers an open sunny position in a well-drained moisture retentive soil. Hardy to about -15c. At one time this plant was extensively grown for its edible leaves and stems but it has now fallen into virtual disuse, having been replaced by celery. In Europe wild populations of alexanders grow abundantly in salt-marshes and uncultivated land near the sea. normally in lime soils. It is also found in hedges. woods and on waysides.

Name: Iraqi Allium
Notes: Allium anacoleum is a plant species native to Turkey and Iraq. It is a herbaceous, perennial plant growing from an underground bulb. It is a semi-evergreen variety which forms clumps of long narrow leaves, topped in summer with drumsticks pastel flowers. The small bulb is formed on a short rhizome - as more bulbs are produced the plant develops into a moderate-sized clump. HABITAT: Rocky areas, grasslands, subhumid pastures, dry rocky slopes near melting snow at an ALTITUDE of 2,400-6,562 feet. Turkey distribution: E. Anatolia - General distribution: N. Iraq - Provinces where it is located: B7 B8 C9. - Element: Iran -Turan. - HABITAT: Damp meadows near rivers. Flood-plain meadows, birch groves. Chalk & sand. - POLLINATION: Bees, butterflies & Insects. PROPAGATION: Seed, bulbs, or by division. PROPAGATION: Seed, bulbs, or by division.

Name: Lemon Bergamot (Lemon beebalm, Lemon Mint)
Notes: Native to the southern United States and northern Mexico, Lemon Bee Balm is an attractive, if short-lived, plant. Its foliage has a mild lemon or oregano fragrance. Lemon Bee Balm can be distinguished from most Monarda spp. (Bee Balms) in Illinois by its more narrow leaves, which are somewhat downy-pubescent, and by its annual or biennial habit. Known by a number of common names, lemon beebalm is a 1-2 ft., aromatic winter annual with unusual, tuft-like, lavender to pink, whorled flower heads. Each whorl in the elongated spike is subtended by whitish or lavender, leaf-like bracts. HABITAT: Prairie, Plains, Meadows, Pastures, Savannas, Hillsides, Slopes. It is susceptible to powdery mildew. ELEVATION: 4,000–8,500 feet. PROPAGATION: Seeds. Once established, should reseed itself. Seeding rate is 3 pounds/acre. There are approximately 819,000 seeds/pound. In rich soil with abundant moisture, this wildflower may become excessively tall and topple over.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Essential Oil, Essential Oil, Food, Insect Repellent, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Burdock
Notes: Burdock is cultivated for its edible root in Japan and has a long history of medicinal use. Propagation: Seed - best sown in situ in the autumn. The seed can also be sown in spring. Germination can be erratic, it is best to sow the seed in trays and plant out the young plants before the tap-root develops. Seed requires a minimum temperature of 10°c, but a temperature of 20 - 25°c is optimum. Germination rates can be improved by pre-soaking the seed for 12 hours or by scarification. They germinate best in the light. The autumn sowing should be made as late as possible because any plants with roots more than 3mm in diameter in the spring will quickly run to seed if cold temperatures are followed by daylengths longer than 12½ hours. Greater burdock is recognized by its feltless capitula and the yellow hooked tips of their involucral bracts. Woolly burdock (A. tomentosum; also known as downy burdock ), whose capitulum has a woolly covering, is much more common, as is the slightly smaller lesser burdock (A. minus). Burdocks that grow together easily cross-breed, and part of the greater burdock stand is actually comprised of hybrids between greater and lesser burdock. Reduces the value
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Dynamic Accumulator, Insectory, Soil Cultivator, Wildlife Food
Human Use/Crop: Essential Oil, Food, Food, Food, Food, Food, Food, Food, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Celery
Notes: Celery is a widely cultivated biennial that grows wild in salty soils.

Name: Chervil
Notes: Lacy, fern-like leaves with delicate white flowers

Name: Land Cress
Notes: non mycorrhizal. Other names for upland cress are land cress, dryland cress, cassabully, and creasy salad.

Name: Curly-top Gumweed
Notes: Well adapted to drought conditions and sandy soils.

Name: Larger Tinsel Flower (Slangwortel, Ikhathazo)
Notes: Alepidea amatymbica is a robust, erect perennial herb, up to 79 inches tall. The stem is hollow, grooved, branched, with a large, aromatic root stock of numerous slightly fleshy roots up to .98 inches in diameter. Bi/Annual, Perennial. RANGE: SA Distribution: Eastern Cape, Free State, Gauteng, KwaZulu-Natal, Limpopo, Mpumalanga. - Fruits are egg-shaped and seeds are flat on one side and curved on the other side. HABITAT: Damp grasslands near streams. It is common in the summer rainfall grasslands of southern Africa. - ELEVATION: 4,987 to 8,497 feet. The genus name Alepidea means ‘without a scale’, from the Greek a-, meaning without, and lepis meaning ‘a scale’. This species is named after the amaThembu, people whose historical territory is the former Transkei, now in the Eastern Cape, where this plant occurs. PROPAGATION: Seed or Division. Fresh seed is the best method.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Insect Repellent, Medicine, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Foxglove
Notes: Grows well on average, well-draining soils; best if they are organically rich. It produces many seeds and self-sows freely in agreeable conditions. Produces a basal rosette its first year. Strawberry foxglove hardy to zone 3.
Human Use/Crop: Container Garden, Cut Flower, Dye, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Robert Geranium
Notes: Annual or biennial.

Name: Lawndaisy
Notes: Pink and white flowers; self-sows easily;makes a good cut flower
Human Use/Crop: Cut Flower, Food, Insect Repellent, Medicine

Name: Wild Lettuce
Notes: Wild Lettuce commonly refers to the more bitter cousins of common garden lettuce. This group of plants is used in everything from sleep tonics to soap to teas. The three main species of this group are Lactuca Virosa, Lactuca Canadennis, and Lactuca Serrio

Name: Lavender Globe Lily
Notes: Foliage lush into late summer

Name: Chinese Milkvetch
Notes: Winter cover crop / forage on rice fields.Aka milchwicke, genge, renge-so, jaunyeong. Propagation Seed - best sown as soon as it is ripe in a cold frame. A period of cold stratification may help stored seed to germinate. Stored seed, and perhaps also fresh seed, should be pre-soaked for 24 hours in hot water before sowing - but make sure that you do not cook the seed. Any seed that does not swell should be carefully pricked with a needle, taking care not to damage the embryo, and re-soaked for a further 24 hours. Germination can be slow and erratic but is usually within 4 - 9 weeks or more at 13°c if the seed is treated or sown fresh. As soon as it is large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and grow them on in the greenhouse for their first winter, planting them out into their permanent positions in late spring or early summer, after the last expected frosts.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Groundcover, Nitrogen Fixer, Soil Builder

Name: Common Mullein
Notes: It is in flower from June to August, and the seeds ripen from August to September. The flowers are hermaphrodite (have both male and female organs) and are pollinated by Flies and Lepidoptera (Moths & Butterflies). The plant is self-fertile. The common mullein seed bank is persistent. Seeds have germinated after 100 years or more in the soil. Rarely is common mullein described in undisturbed communities. The creation of sunny, open sites by heavy grazing, severe storms, logging, fire, or other disturbances is generally necessary for common mullein establishment, growth, and reproductive success.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Biomass, Dye, Fiber, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Cow Parsley
Notes: Cultivar Ravenswing has reddish stems and deep green foliage.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Insecticide, Insectory, Insectory

Name: Virginia Pepperweed (Common Pepperweed)
Notes: Annual or biennial. Initially a low-growing rosette. Flowering peaks during early summer. Leaves may turn yellow during drought. Easily reseeds. Non mycorrhizal. Seed pods are spread as contaminant of grains, in animal wool and by birds. Non mycorhizal
Human Use/Crop: Dried Flower, Food, Food, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Armenian poppy
Notes: Papaver armeniacum, the Armenian poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the family, native to the Caucasus region; Iran, Iraq, North Caucasus, Transcaucasus, Turkey. Biennial species with pale orange papery bowls on pyramid-like flower stems and lovely, prickly grey-green rosettes. It produces the benzylisoquinoline alkaloid armepavine (6 7 methoxy 1 (4' hydroxy benzyl) 1234 tetrahydro isoquinoline). Papaver armeniacum is very similar to the Anatolian poppy ( Papaver triniifolium ), another Turkish poppy species. Biennial species with pale orange papery bowls on pyramid-like flower stems and lovely, prickly grey-green rosettes. This poppy is worth growing for its foliage alone. monocarpic, unusual. PROPAGATION: Seeds. Exposure to cold may not be necessary for flowering but might improve quality. POLLINATION: Bees. Deciduous, Semi-Evergreen. -- The following subspecies are accepted: Papaver armeniacum subsp. armeniacum, Papaver armeniacum subsp. microstigmum (Boiss.) Kadereit, Papaver armeniacum subsp. pilgerianum (Fedde) Kadereit.

Name: Evening Primrose
Notes: These plants do best in well-drained soils in full sun. They can be easily grown from seed. The seeds are ripe when the seed capsule begins to split open, usually in October. To insure even planting, mix the seeds with a small amount of sand prior to sowing. The seeds usually germinate within four weeks. Thereafter, the plants will generally self-sow. Seeds buried I the soil maintain germination ability for many years.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Dried Flower, Dye, Food, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Spanish Salsify (Scorzonera)
Notes: "Grows well in an ordinary garden soil in sun or semi-shade[200]. Prefers a rich soil. This species has sometimes been cultivated in the past for its edible root.

Name: Scorpionweed (Variable-leaf Phacelia)
Notes: A bee magnet! This delightful biennial or short-lived perennial wildflower can grow 2′-4′ tall. The charming, coiled whitish-cream-colored, bell-shaped flowers bloom May-June, and like other phacelias, have protruding stamens. Varileaf phacelia usually produces just a single, tall flowering stem that can be either green or red. All parts of the plant are bristly or glandular hairy. Grows from a taproot on foothill slopes, rock outcrops, ridgelines, well-drained or rocky flats, in chaparral, and other dry, open locations at low to high elevations. Prefers full sun or part shade. . A great species for dryland pollinator gardens and habitat restoration. 30 days cold-moist stratification. Sow outside in fall or early spring. Seeds need light to germinate, surface sow.
Ecological Function: Insectory, Reclamator, Reclamator, Soil Builder, Soil Cultivator, Toxin Absorber

Name: White Sweetclover
Notes: Yellow and white sweetclover occupy similar nonnative habitats and are often associated with disturbances. In California, Nevada, and Florida, sweetclover is primarily restricted to recently disturbed sites. Although yellow and white sweetclover are more alike than different, the following morphological differences are common: White sweetclover is generally taller, has a more erect form, and produces coarser stems and branches than yellow sweetclover, reviews by; white sweetclover may be up to 3 feet (1 m) taller than yellow sweetclover. At peak flowering, white sweetclover racemes are much longer (8-15 times) than those of yellow sweetclover. Leaflets produced by yellow sweetclover are often twice as wide as those produced by white sweetclover. Yellow sweetclover legumes are wrinkled, and white sweetclover legumes are veiny
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Dynamic Accumulator, Erosion Control, Insectory, Nitrogen Fixer, Nurse, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Food, Insect Repellent, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Yellow Sweetclover
Notes: Yellow flowers in second year of growth. Soil seed bank lasts from 17 to 50 years. Differences between white and yellow sweetclovers are as follows: White sweetclover is generally taller, has a more erect form, and produces coarser stems and branches than yellow sweetclover, white sweetclover may be up to 3 feet (1 m) taller than yellow sweetclover. At peak flowering, white sweetclover racemes are much longer (8-15 times) than those of yellow sweetclover. Leaflets produced by yellow sweetclover are often twice as wide as those produced by white sweetclover. Yellow sweetclover legumes are wrinkled, and white sweetclover legumes are veiny.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Dynamic Accumulator, Erosion Control, Insectory, Nitrogen Fixer, Nurse, Nurse, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Food, Insect Repellent, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Tall Thistle
Notes: Plant size can vary significantly in different environmental conditions. May be a short-lived perennial or biennial. Forms a short rosette in alternate years.

Name: Wild Turnip
Notes: "Succeeds in full sun in a well-drained fertile preferably alkaline soil. Succeeds in any reasonable soil but prefers one on the heavy side[16]. Tolerates a pH in the range 4.8 to 8.3. This is the wild form of the turnip with a non-tuberous tap-root. It is closely related to the cultivated forms that are grown for their edible oil-bearing seeds. This species is native to Eurasia, but has spread all over the world and is now naturalized throughout much of North America. It grows from sea level to 5,000 ft. " Field mustard grows in disturbed areas including roadsides, ditches, cultivated fields, orchards, and gardens.
Ecological Function: Chemical Barrier, Domestic Animal Forage, Dynamic Accumulator, Erosion Control, Insecticide, Insectory, Soil Builder
Human Use/Crop: Biomass, Food, Medicine, Oil, Wax, Resin or Polish, Oil, Wax, Resin or Polish, Soap

Name: Stinking Wall Rocket (Stinkweed)
Notes: Very resistant to heat, this plant could be used as a perennial substitute for Eruca vesicaria sativa, the annual rocket, in hot summer areas. It is most frequent in waste places such as by railways, roads and on tips, but is also found on rocks, cliffs, walls and in gardens. Sowing depth: 0.5cm (0.2in). Sprinkle the seeds on the surface of the soil and barely cover. Spacing: 12-18in (30-45cm) apart. Light: full sun/partial shade. Watering: regular to keep the soil moist, but not soggy. Fertilizing: recommended. Non mycorrhizal.

Name: White Wall Rocket (Wild Rocket)
Notes: A weed of arable and waste ground in S. England and frequent as a casual. Plants often germinate in the autumn and survive as an over-wintering rosette. Non mycorrhizal.
